rounds.comments: (Ken: Name the woman who penned each line.)

clues.text: "I think it (makes God angry) if you walk by the color purple in a field somewhere and don't notice it"
"No need to add that my being happy in Forks is an impossibility"
In the introduction to her diary, "The climax of our struggle... came when our first baby was kidnapped... on March 1st, 1932"
"Some day they'll go down together / They'll bury them side by side / To few it'll be grief / To the law a relief"
"He is jubilant as a flag unfurled-/Oh, a girl, she'd not forget him./My own dear love, he is all my world,-/& I wish I'd never met him"

rounds.category: FROM THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE GLOSSARY

clues.text: J: "A structure... extending into a sea, lake, or river to influence the current or tide"
D: "A region of low atmospheric pressure that is usually accompanied by low clouds & precipitation"
F: "A rapid & extreme flow of high water into a normally dry area... beginning within 6 hours of the causative event"

I:
"A line connecting points of equal pressure"
F: "(or F scale)-a scale of tornado intensity"
To hear something with thoughtful attention & making no sound
In the buff & a crescent-shaped sand mound
A glowing streak in the sky & an adjective meaning distant
The main enemy of a novel's hero & a situation of no economic growth
One bead of fluid from the lacrimal gland & an animal that attacks other animals
Wilson Greatbatch was trying to record heart sounds, but using an incorrect resistor led him to invent the first implantable this
John Walker scraped some combustible materials he'd been mixing off the wooden stirrer & it burst into flames; this was born
Albert Hofmann was out to discover new stimulants when he accidentally dosed himself with this drug; pretty groovy
He returned from a summer vacation to find a contaminated Petri dish, leading to the discovery of penicillin
One of his signature effects used in early films like "A Trip to the Moon" was created when the film in his camera jammed up
Coming up this river to attack Paris in the 9th c., Vikings were met by the garrison of Odo, who repulsed them-& turned them back
This man's forces won the Battle of the Jhelum River in Asia in 326 B.C., but advanced no farther & turned back for home
In 1916 a group who resented this healer's influence shot him, then threw his body in the Neva River
Including Singidunum, a series of fortresses known as the Limes on this river marked the northern boundary of the Roman empire
This longest river in Spain was the site of a bloody 1938 battle ending in a Republican defeat & Catalonia's isolation
In a kids' book, we meet this title character along with his siblings Flopsy, Mopsy & Cotton-tail
Quixada, Quesada or even Quexana may have been the original surname of the character who chose this name for himself
At the end of an 1831 novel, his skeleton is found in a cellar with a curved spine & soon crumbles into dust
A drug addict named William Lee is the narrator of this novel by William S. Burroughs
Jilted as a bride, she calls Satis House home in "Great Expectations"
If you need a helpful hunt deity, Mixcoatl comes highly recommended by these Tenochtitlan residents
Her boss-dad Zeus calls her a headache, but here on the Acropolis, we call her Pallas
This god got a bad performance review when he failed to smash the skull of Jörmungandr; he'll have another shot at Ragnarök
If you're looking for a bountiful harvest, this Roman goddess of grains really reaps it in
This consort of Shiva is great at vanquishing foes but she insists her belt of severed hands is business casual; don't tell HR
Before it was a toy, it meant a swindler who switched boxes of coins during a transaction
The 1920s gave us this word for a beat-up old car
This word for a type of caretaker comes from the name of a minor Roman deity
This word for a type of cutting tool comes from the name of a dance that involves a similar up & down motion
It can be any kind of big, festive gathering, no longer just of Boy Scouts
It's something of little importance or value, like, say, legumes in a heap
In a 1785 poem William Cowper referred to this as "the very spice of life"; spoken like a man who's never tried sriracha
At the dinner table, it can be a tempting item, perhaps twice baked-or a subject best avoided
TV's "MythBusters" once tested whether "taking" this is "as easy" as the idiom suggests-conclusion: nope
This 3-word term once referred to a vessel for boiling the catch at river picnics; today, "fine" or not, it means a hot mess
Bicycles take flight thanks to the magical powers of a mysterious alien in this Spielberg flick
"Raindrops Keep Fallin' On My Head" plays as Paul Newman hams it up on a bike in this film that co-starred Robert Redford
A bit of movie magic allowed this green guy to take a bike ride in 1979 & 1981 films
In a 2025 HBO Max doc, Paul Reubens said people riding bicycles around the WB lot inspired the stolen-bike plot of this movie
In "Better Off Dead" a psychotic paperboy pedals after this actor in pursuit of the $2 he's owed
Also called nicotinic acid, it gets better publicity as a vitamin under this name
It's paired with preen in an idiom meaning to make oneself beautiful
This type of place that makes & serves beer foamed up in the '80s, with California's first being fittingly in Hopland
Lye is also known as this type of soda, meaning it can corrode by chemical action
From the French for "explore", the military does it to get information

General Douglas MacArthur,
Syngman Rhee

Saddam Hussein,
"Stormin' Norman" Schwarzkopf

Major-General Sir Colin Campbell,
Florence Nightingale

George Washington,
Marquis de Montcalm

Henry V,
Joan of Arc

rounds.text: The winning word at the first Scripps National Spelling Bee was this, a plant & genus with sword-shaped leaves now on the trophy
